prs.title: DEVREL-126 feat: validate Solana admin address for delegate/owner when wiring
prs.truncated_body:
## Summary
- for Solana, we expect the `owner` or `delegate` address to be an on curve address or a Squads vault address (and not the multisig account address)
- however, right now we don't have any checks to enforce the above
- this PR introduces those checks

## Changes

- Introduced in `packages/devtools-solana` a helper to ensure an address is not a Multisig Account address
- used this

prs.title: Explicit error handling in LocalRegistry to check for empty registry
prs.truncated_body:
Previously the LocalNode() method in LocalRegistry would work even if the registry was empty.
Now adding explicit checks to fail all calls to LocalRegistry if it is empty.
Assumption is that any workflow job will only work if workflow registry is pre-populated. There are some tests which weren't following this, but they will be fixed separately.


Slack thread: https://chainlink-core.slack.co

ONDISCONNECT handler calls `sanitize(url)` before logging the event. `sanitize()` wasn't expecting partial urls, i.e. those starting with '?'.

Tests do not exercise `StreamingClient.connection`'s ONDISCONNECT handler locally, but they do in CI. The reason for that is not known. Do note though that the handler does nothing beyond logging the event.

prs.title: feat(zoneconcierge): BSN Header synchronization  (backport #1331)
prs.truncated_body:
New flow optimized for BSN header synchronization:

BSN connects --> Babylon sets BSN base header to current tip
Babylon sends headers from base to tip --> BSN processes them
If reorg occurs --> Babylon falls back to BSN base header

The implementation also includes BSNs updating their base header via IBC packet for more flexible synchronization.

Closes - https://github.com/babylonlabs-io/babylon

prs.title: miner: fix deadlock and panic issues in block production
prs.truncated_body:
# Description

These fixes address production issues where mining nodes would deadlock for hours after milestone-triggered reorgs, unable to  process new blocks or respond to chain updates.

  - Skip stale sealed blocks that are behind current chain head to prevent resultLoop from attempting to write outdated blocks after reorgs
  - Add 1-second timeout to chDeps channel send to prevent indef

commits.message:
miner: fix deadlock and panic issues in block production

  - Skip stale sealed blocks that are behind current chain head to prevent
    resultLoop from attempting to write outdated blocks after reorgs
  - Add 1-second timeout to chDeps channel send to prevent indefinite
    blocking when receiver is dead or channel is full
  - Return error when transaction count exceeds dependency list length
    to prevent array index out of bounds panic

  These fixes address production issues where mining nodes would deadlock
  for hours after milestone-triggered reorgs, unable to
  process new blocks or respond to chain updates.

commits.message:
pack: reject bundles with conflicting nonce txns

Bundles with two conflicting nonce transactions are guaranteed
to fail.  Technically, the block engine should never send us such
transactions.  Adds defense-in-depth to prevent the noncemap from
having two entries for the same key.  (The pack tile handled such
a scenario gracefully before, but it may become unsound in the
future with map_chain with MAP_MULTI==0)

- Improve fd_pack_verify (check sig2txn, noncemap, pool roots)

sysctl net.ipv4.conf.lo.route_localnet must be set to 1 on newer
kernels, to avoid a drop at the following check:

https://elixir.bootlin.com/linux/v6.11/source/net/ipv4/route.c#L2255

This is presumably a kernel bug ...

Reported-by: TheDude <mark@temporal.xyz>

Closes https://github.com/firedancer-io/firedancer/issues/565

commits.message:
Fix XDP loopback packet loss

When sending packets from/to localhost via the lo interface, the
sysctl net.ipv4.conf.lo.route_localnet must be set to 1 on newer
kernels, to avoid a drop at the following check:

https://elixir.bootlin.com/linux/v6.11/source/net/ipv4/route.c#L2255

This is presumably a kernel bug ...

Reported-by: TheDude <mark@temporal.xyz>

prs.title: Do not evaluate globally accepted block proposals
prs.truncated_body:
This was a cleanup suggested by @obycode when going through logs. 

We were seeing signers processing a NewBlock event for stacks block N. 
Then receiving a block proposal message delayed for stacks block N. 
Signer would then query the tip of the node and see that the tip had advanced to stacks block height N. This would cause signer to respond with a rejection with InvalidParentBlock even th

commits.message:
Do not evaluate globally accepted block proposals

prs.truncated_body:
Existing behavior didn't allow implicit volumes with default settings, for example

```yaml
services:
  ollama:
    image: "docker.io/ollama/ollama"
    ports:
      - "11434:11434"
    volumes:
      - ollama-storage:/root/.ollama
    entrypoint: ["/usr/bin/bash", "-c", "/bin/ollama serve & sleep 5; ollama pull ${OLLAMA_MODEL}; wait"]

volumes:
  ollama-storage:
```

Existing behavior didn't allow implicit volumes with default settings.

prs.title: refactor: re-exec loop check
prs.truncated_body:
## Why this should be merged

`reprocessState` unnecessarily re-executes up to `bc.commitInterval` blocks in some cases, when the most recent commit occurs at the acceptor tip.

## How this works

Instead of immediately decrementing the block number to check, the current block is checked first.

## How this was tested

Additional unit tests were created to ensure equivalent functionality

prs.title: Lock tracking
prs.truncated_body:
## Description

This update introduces internal tracking for lock operations and adds depth validation to prevent excessively nested lock structures.

### Changes:
- **State additions:**
  - `LOCK_ID_TRACKING`: tracks forward composition (split/merge relationships).
  - `REVERSE_LOCK_ID_TRACKING`: maps each lock to its parent(s).
  - `LOCK_ID_EXPIRY`: stores expiry timestamps for lock IDs.

commits.message:
- implemented forward and reverse lock tracking when splitting and merging
- added get_current_lock_composition and get_lock_ancestor_depth methods
Continue instead of returning 0 in get_lock_ancestor depth loop, + add cases to test
make root count as depth 1, add docstrings to get_current_lock_composition and get_lock_ancestor_depth

Fix bug in Bytes.lastIndexOf when array is empty and position is not 2²⁵⁶-1
prs.truncated_body:
Fix bug introduced in #5252 (v5.2)

#### Bug description

If the `buffer` is empty and if `pos` is not `type(uint256).max`
  - in the computation of `Math.min(pos, length - 1) + 1`, `length-1` overflow and return `2²⁵⁶-1`.
  - taking the min between `pos` and that will return something that is NOT `2²⁵⁶-1`.
  - adding 1 to it will NOT return 0.
  - the loop will start at a non-0 index, and

commits.message: Fix bug in Bytes.lastIndexOf when array is empty and position is not 2²⁵⁶-1
independant fuzz tests of  and  without pos
use Math.saturatingAdd to more closelly match original syntax

prs.truncated_body:
## Description

<!--

-->

This PR improves the restart resilience of the bridge node in the following ways:

1. **Atomic Updates into Persistence**
   Previously, the bridge node persisted current machine state after processing of a block in two phases -- old contracts were persisted first and then, contracts from the new block

commits.message: fix(duty-tracker): use max deposit idx of all active contracts as offset
fix(duty-tracker): persist all contract states post-block-processing atomically
feat(p2p-service): add ouroboros req channel for self-nagging

multi: make the ouroboros system mediate all access to the p2p network

This change makes it such that we route all messages and message
requests through the ouroboros (OB) channel system.

Prior to this change messages were sent over the MessageHandler which
sent messages to the OB channel and the p2p network at the "same time".
This means that in practice we would send messages to the p2p network
prior to us fully committing all changes that result from that message
to disk. This creates a nasty edge case where if a node crashes after
it sends the message to the network and before it processes the effects
of its own message, it would result in that nodes state falling behind
its peers.

This reveals what I believe to be a latent requirement: the network
should never become aware of an outbound message before our internal
state is fully synchronized to incorporate the effects of that message.

To accomplish this we remove the `P2PHandle` from the `MessageHandler`
entirely. All messages are sent only to the OB channel. From there in
the event handler for the OB channel, we process that message. Only
if it succeeds, do we forward it to the rest of the network.

As a corollary, we forward all `GetMessageRequest`s through the OB
request channel that we use for "self-nags". In the handler for the
OB message requests, we peel off the ones meant for us and emit the
necessary duties, and otherwise we forward the request to the rest
of the network.
